data.title: Top 30 Most Influential Worship Songs (1994-2024)
data.meta_description: The worship song â€œShout to the Lordâ€ is how old?! To be sure, worship music had been in existence prior to Hillsong Church and Darlene Zschech via Maranathaâ€¦
data.text:
The worship song â€œShout to the Lordâ€ is how old?! Yup, if you can believe it, the tune that some say started the turn of CCM to its current worship bent, is celebrating thirty years in 2024.

To be sure, worship music had been in existence prior to Hillsong Church and Darlene Zschech via Maranatha and Vineyard, but nothing quite like the worldwide smash â€œShout to the Lord.â€

Well, I began thinking about the other influential worship songs of the last 25-30 years and my cynicism quickly turned to enthusiasm as I began making a mental list of others Iâ€™d put in that category. That list reached more than twenty before I knew it so I figured Iâ€™d just keep going and match the anniversary of the song (30 years) with thirty songs I think had the biggest influence on the worldwide church in that span.

Full warning: this is not a deeply researched list. I simply went from memory of what Iâ€™ve experienced, read about, and heard the last thirty years. Iâ€™m sure there are plenty of gaps that others can fill in, this is simply a conversation starter and celebration of what I think were/are the cream of the crop. Please add yours too.

Anyway, here we are. Thank you for checking out the list. If youâ€™ve read my blog/lists before you may be expecting it to be ranked, but I decided against it, simply looking to identify the thirty most â€œinfluentialâ€ or what I think are the â€œessentialsâ€ of congregational-directed songs. I also decided to go with a one-song per artist rule to highlight as many artists as possible. They are in order of the year they released starting with 1994 and working up to the present day in 2024 at the time of this writing.

You may also enjoy: These 5 Albums â€œAltaredâ€ the Christian Music Industry

Lastly, I included an additional twenty of my personal favorites and will link my All-time Favorites Worship Playlist of nearly 200 songs which I sourced this list from at the end of that post.

Here we go!

â€œShout to the Lordâ€ â€“ Darlene Zschech (Hillsong Worship) (1994)

â€œBetter is One Dayâ€ â€“ Matt Redman (1995)

â€œBreatheâ€ â€“ Marie Barnett (1996)

â€œI Could Sing of Your Love Foreverâ€ â€“ Delirious (1997)

It was a simple staple of the era.

â€œDays of Elijahâ€ â€“ Robin Mark (1997)

â€œTrading My Sorrows (Yes Lord)â€ â€“ Darrell Evans (1998)

â€œThe Heart of Worshipâ€ â€“ Matt Redman (1998)

One could make an argument that this is the most â€œimportantâ€ worship song of the last 30 years and youâ€™d get no argument from me. we still need it more than ever.

â€œAbove Allâ€ â€“ Lenny Leblanc/Paul Baloche (2000)

â€œGod of Wondersâ€ â€“ Marc Byrd/Steve Hindalong (2000)

Aside from â€œShout to the Lordâ€ or â€œHeart of Worshipâ€ this is the first worship song I remember dominating worship sets in nearly every church across America.

â€œOpen the Eyes of My Heartâ€ â€“ Paul Baloche (2000)

â€œHere I Am to Worshipâ€ â€“ Tim Hughes (2001)

â€œHow Great is Our Godâ€ â€“ Chris Tomlin (2004)

This one celebrate twenty years in 2024! This one may have surpassed â€œShout to the Lordâ€ as THE most sung and known song overall. It would certainly be in the convo for #1 if I were ranking the list.

â€œFriend of Godâ€ â€“ Israel Houghton/Michael Gungor (2003)

â€œHow He Lovesâ€ â€“ John Mark McMillan (2005)

Oh who could forget the â€œsloppy wet kissâ€ vs. David Crowder Bandâ€™s change of lyric on their cover to â€œunforeseen kiss?!â€ More importantly, which lyric do you like better?! ğŸ˜‚ Iâ€™m unashamedly team â€œsloppy wet kissâ€ and prefer JMMâ€™s version. The story behind the song may surprise you and is definitely worth looking up if youâ€™re curious, as is Johnâ€™s emotionally gut-wrenching version on his album The Song Inside the Sounds of Breaking Down.

â€œJesus Paid it Allâ€ â€“ Kristian Stanfill (Passion) (2006)

Both this tune and the one below it brought in some hymns to be modernized or hymn-like structure that I wish were utilized more in our present worship leading. Itâ€™s needed and appreciated by us old guys. ğŸ˜‰

â€œIn Christ Aloneâ€ â€“ Keith & Kristin Getty (2006)

â€œRevelation Songâ€ â€“ Kari Jobe/Gateway Church (2006)

The song was inescapable for the rest of the decade from 2006 forward with multiple covers from other artists keeping it evergreen. Well deserved. Songwriter Jennie Lee Riddle really nails it and Kari Jobe brought it to life vocally.

â€œEverlasting Godâ€ â€“ Brenton Brown (2006)

â€œYour Love Never Failsâ€ â€“ Chris McClarney (2008)

Gods Not Dead (Like a Lion) â€“ Daniel Bashta (2010)

Covered by both David Crowder Band and then again by The Newsboys, the song also inspired a movie franchise. Iâ€™ll take Crowderâ€™s version from Passion: Awakening (2010).

â€œHoly Spiritâ€ â€“ Bryan & Katie Torwalt (2012)

â€œOceans (Where Feet May Fail)â€ â€“ Hillsong United (2013)

Hereâ€™s another pivot point song for worship music. This. Song. Was. HUGE. I truly believe the entire CCM industry was swung way to the worship side from this point forward.

â€œThis is Amazing Graceâ€ â€“ Phil Wickham (2013)

â€œGood Good Fatherâ€ â€“ House fires/Pat Barrett (2015)

â€œWaymakerâ€ â€“ Sinach (2015)

Written by Nigerian-gospel singer Sinach, Leeland and Michael W. Smith brought this truly great song to a much wider audience. Terrific tune.

â€œReckless Loveâ€ â€“ Cory Asbury (2017)

Another hotly debated songâ€¦is Godâ€™s love reckless? Is it calculated? I know one thing tor site, itâ€™s mysterious and glorious. Also, Asbury is a top-notch writer worth digging into his greater catalogue.

â€œGoodness of Godâ€ â€“ Bethel Music (2019)

This one still dominates CCLI charts and is song regularly almost 5 years later, and thatâ€™s pretty hard to do in the worship scene/music industry that is becoming churning over songs quicker and quicker the more the market is flooded with them.

â€œThe Blessingâ€ â€“ Kari Jobe/Cody Carnes (2020)

â€œGraves into Gardensâ€ â€“ Brandon Lake (Elevation Church) (2020)

â€œJirehâ€ â€“ Maverick City (2021)

This collective of worshippers known as Maverick City has taken the genre by storm in relatively quick fashion. Since 2019 Iâ€™d venture a guess that no worship artist or church worship has been as prolific with new songs, EPs, albums, or collaborations.

20 Additional Favorites:

â€œHosannaâ€ â€“ Brooks Fraser (Hillsong United (2007)

â€œBlessed Be the Nameâ€ â€“ Matt Redman (2002)

â€œLord, I Need Youâ€ â€“ Matt Maher (2013)

â€œGreat Are You Lordâ€ â€“ All Sons & Daughters (2014)

â€œO Come to the Altarâ€ â€“ Elevation Worship (2015)

â€œ10,000 Reasonsâ€ â€“ Matt Redman (2013)

â€œDeath Was Arrestedâ€ â€“ Northpoint Church (2018)

â€œTrembleâ€ â€“ Mosaic MSC (2016)

â€œWho You Say I Amâ€ â€“ Brooke Fraser/Hillsong Worship (2018)

â€œWhat a Beautiful Nameâ€ â€“ Brooke Fraser/Hillsong Worship (2017)

â€œYou Wonâ€™t Relentâ€ â€“ Misty Edwards/Jesus Culture (2008)

â€œNo Longer Slavesâ€ â€“ Johnathan & Melissa Hesler/Bethel (2015)

â€œFirm Foundation (He Wonâ€™t)â€ â€“ Cody Carnes (2023)

â€œIs He Worthy?â€ â€“ Andrew Peterson (2018)

â€œAmazing Grace (My Chains Are Gone)â€ â€“ Chris Tomlin (2006)

â€œGratitudeâ€ â€“ Brandon Lake (2020)

â€œHe Knows My Heartâ€ â€“ Tommy Walker (1999)

â€œLove Noteâ€ â€“ UPPERROOM (2021)

â€œBreak Every Chainâ€ â€“ Will Reagan & United Pursuit (2009)

â€œNo One Like Youâ€ â€“ David Crowder Band (2002)

Whew! Thatâ€™s fifty songs, and of course there are many others with perhaps your favorite not making my list. Or maybe I have an egregious unintentional snub, and if so (itâ€™s likely) please let me know in the comments. I have been known to retroactively take a readers suggestion from time to time.

Alright, hereâ€™s the promised 200 Song Worship Mix. Enjoy!

-Josh
